tit.cmt: タイトルなので (Nagako)削除しました。

sen.j: 良子内親王（りょうし（ながこ）ないしんのう、長元2年12月13日 (旧暦)（1030年1月25日） - 承暦元年8月26日 (旧暦)（1077年9月15日））は、第67代後朱雀天皇第一皇女。
sen.e: Imperial Princess Ryoshi (Nagako), January 25, 1030 - September 15, 1077, was the first daughter of Emperor Gosuzaku, the sixty-seventh emperor of Japan.
Imperial Princess Ryoshi (Nagako), January 25, 1030 - September 15, 1077, was the first daughter of Emperor Gosuzaku, the sixty-seventh emperor of Japan.
Imperial Princess Ryoshi (Nagako), January 25, 1030 - September 21, 1077, was the first daughter of Emperor Gosuzaku, the sixty-seventh Emperor of Japan.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に訂正しました。Emperor大文字にしました。

sen.e: Her mother was Empress Teishi (Yoshiko/Sadako) who was an imperial princess.
Her mother was Empress Teishi (Yoshiko/Sadako) who was an imperial princess.
Her mother was Empress Teishi (Yoshiko/Sadako) who was an Imperial Princess.
sen.cmt: Imperial Princess大文字にしました。

sen.e: Imperial Princess Ryoshi was granted Ippon Jugo (the highest rank of nobility after the Grand Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager and the Empress) and was Saigu (Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Ise-jingu Shrine).

Imperial Princess Ryoshi was granted Ippon Jugo (the highest rank of nobility after the Grand Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager and the Empress) and was Saigu (Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Ise-jingu Shrine).

Imperial Princess Ryoshi was granted Ippon Jugo (the highest rank of nobility after the Grand Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager and the Empress) and was Saigu (Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Ise-jingu Shrine).

sen.j: 同母妹に娟子内親王（斎院）、同母弟に第69代後三条天皇がいる。
sen.e: Imperial Princess Keishi (Saiin or Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Kamo-jinja Shrines) was her uterine younger sister and Emperor Gosanjo, the sixty-ninth emperor, was her uterine younger brother.

Imperial Princess Keishi (Saiin or Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Kamo-jinja Shrines) was her uterine younger sister and Emperor Gosanjo, the sixty-ninth emperor, was her uterine younger brother.

Imperial Princess Keishi (Saiin or Imperial Princess appointed to serve the deities of the Kamo-jinja Shrines) was her uterine younger sister and Emperor Gosanjo, the sixty-ninth emperor, was her uterine younger brother.

sen.j: 長元9年（1036年）11月28日、父後朱雀天皇即位に伴い8歳で斎宮卜定。
sen.e: On November 28, 1036 when her father, Emperor Gosuzaku acceded to the throne, Princess Ryoshi was selected as the Saigu by divination at the age of eight.
On November 28, 1036 when her father, Emperor Gosuzaku acceded to the throne, Princess Ryoshi was selected as Saigu by divination at the age of eight.
On December 24, 1036 when her father, Emperor Gosuzaku acceded to the throne, Princess Ryoshi was selected as Saigu by divination at the age of eight.

sen.j: 同年12月、親王宣下と共に二品。
sen.e: In December of the same year she was awarded by the Emperor the title of imperial princess with a rank of Nippon (the second highest rank of nobility).
In December of the same year she was awarded by the Emperor the title of imperial princess with a rank of Nippon (the second highest rank of nobility).
In December of the same year she was awarded by the Emperor the title of Imperial Princess with a rank of Nippon (the second highest rank of nobility).
sen.cmt: Imperial Princess 大文字にしました。

sen.j: 長暦元年（1037年）4月3日、大膳職へ初斎院入り。
sen.e: On April 3, 1037 she moved to Shosaiin (the Hall of Initial Abstinence) in Daizenshiki (the Office of the Imperial Kitchen).
On April 3, 1037 she moved to Shosaiin (the Hall of Initial Abstinence) in Daizenshiki (the Office of the Imperial Kitchen).
On April 27, 1037 she moved to Shosaiin (the Hall of Initial Abstinence) in Daizenshiki (the Office of the Imperial Kitchen).
On September 17 of the same year she moved to Nonomiya (the Field Palace).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On September 17 of the same year she moved to Nonomiya (the Field Palace).
On November 3 of the same year she moved to Nonomiya (the Field Palace).

sen.j: 同2年（1038年）9月11日伊勢国へ下向（長奉送使は中納言藤原資平）。
sen.e: On September 11, 1038 she went down to Ise (escorted by the Councillor, FUJIWARA no Sukehira).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On September 11, 1038 she went down to Ise (escorted by the Councillor, FUJIWARA no Sukehira).
On October 17, 1038 she went down to Ise (escorted by the Councillor, FUJIWARA no Sukehira).
In June 1042 she had the ceremony of Mogi (a ritual celebrating a child's passage into adulthood) and was awarded the rank of Ippon.
In June 1042 she underwent the Mogi ceremony (a ritual celebrating a child's passage into adulthood) and was awarded the rank of Ippon.
In June 1042 she underwent the Mogi ceremony (a ritual celebrating a child's passage into adulthood) and was awarded the rank of Ippon.

sen.j: 寛徳2年（1045年）1月准三宮、同16日、後朱雀天皇譲位により17歳で退下。
sen.e: In January 1045 she was given the title of Jusangu (the highest rank of nobility after the Grand Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager and the Empress) and on January 16 of the same year she retired from her office at the age of seventeen, with Emperor Gosuzaku's abdication.

In January 1045 she was given the title of Jusangu (the highest rank of nobility after the Grand Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager and the Empress) and on January 16 of the same year she retired from her office at the age of seventeen, with Emperor Gosuzaku's abdication.

In January 1045 she was given the title of Jusangu (the highest rank of nobility after the Grand Empress Dowager, the Empress Dowager and the Empress) and on February 11 of the same year she retired from her office at the age of seventeen, with Emperor Gosuzaku's abdication.
sen.cmt: 新暦に訂正しました。スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 同年4月28日に帰京の後は、母禎子内親王の下で弟妹らと暮らしたと思われる。
sen.e: She seems to have lived with her mother Imperial Princess Teishi and siblings after her return from Kyoto on April 28 of the same year.
She seems to have lived with her mother Imperial Princess Teishi and siblings after her return from Kyoto on April 28 of the same year.
She seems to have lived with her mother Imperial Princess Teishi and siblings after her return from Kyoto on May 23 of the same year.

sen.j: 承暦元年（1077年）、天然痘のため49歳で薨去。
sen.e: In 1077 she died of smallpox at the age of forty-nine.
In 1077 she died of smallpox at the age of forty-nine.
In 1077 she died of smallpox at the age of forty-nine.

sen.j: 良子内親王の伊勢下向（群行）に際しては、同行した藤原資房（藤原資平の子）がその日記『春記』に詳細な記録を残している。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Sukefusa (the son of FUJIWARA no Sukehira) who accompanied the imperial princess gave a detailed account of her procession to Ise (gunko) in his diary titled "Shunki."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Sukefusa (the son of FUJIWARA no Sukehira) who accompanied the imperial princess gave a detailed account of her procession to Ise (gunko) in his diary titled "Shunki."
FUJIWARA no Sukefusa (the son of FUJIWARA no Sukehira) who accompanied the Imperial Princess gave a detailed account of her procession to Ise (gunko) in his diary titled "Shunki."
sen.cmt: Imperial Princess 大文字にしました。スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 現在のところ群行に関する唯一の史料として注目されている。
sen.e: This has attracted attention as it is the only historical record of gunko at present.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This has attracted attention as it is the only historical record of gunko at present.
This has attracted attention as it is the only historical record of gunko at present.

sen.j: また長久元年（1040年）5月6日に催された「斎宮良子内親王貝合」は、作者不明の『斎宮貝合日記』により雅やかな儀式の詳細が記されている。
sen.e: Details of an elegant ceremony of 'kaiawase-playing (a kind of concentration using seashells instead of cards) held by the Saigu Ryoshi' on May 6, 1040 were recorded by the anonymous author in "Saigu Kaiawase Nikki" (the Diary of Kaiawase-playing Held by the Saigu).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Details of the elegant ceremony of 'kaiawase-playing (a kind of concentration game using seashells instead of cards) held by the Saigu Ryoshi' on May 6, 1040 was recorded by the anonymous author in "Saigu Kaiawase Nikki" (the Diary of Kaiawase-playing Held by Saigu).

Details of the elegant ceremony of 'kaiawase-playing (a kind of concentration game using seashells instead of cards) held by the Saigu Ryoshi' on June 24, 1040 was recorded by the anonymous author in "Saigu Kaiawase Nikki" (the Diary of Kaiawase-playing Held by Saigu).

sen.j: これも最古の貝合記録として貴重である。
sen.e: This is also a valuable text, being the earliest record of kaiawase.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This is also a valuable text, being the earliest record of kaiawase.
This is also a valuable text, being the earliest record of kaiawase.
